ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned further ASL vocabulary/grammar and Deaf culture.
continuation of ASL, more depth into Deaf culture and history! creative parts of speech
I learned more ASL vocab, classifiers, and storytelling skills while also learning and immersing myself in Deaf culture.

I developed my ability to proficiently use sign language and understood more complex aspects of the grammar and more specific signs such as international cities and medical terms. I also had to work on my communication and organisation skills as there was an ongoing service project throughout the year that required much collaboration and planning,

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: very well taught, engaging in class
Weaknesses: course organization could be improved. Often assignments were unclear, guidelines were changed after assignments were posted, and grading was opaque. More feedback throughout the semester would be great.

Professor Conlin is absolutely a strength of the course! I'd love to see more field trips around campus or in the museums, those were super fun. We didn't really have time for the poetry module this semester so I'd love to see some more of that, and some more time dedicated to the slang, puns, idioms, etc. Oh! and some more opportunities to do narratives. 

The journals and readings absolutely stepped up a level this semester and took some more time, but all of the readings were interesting.

Strengths: extremely interactive and engaging, each class was fun and required us to interact with our classmates and learn more about them

Weakness: a lot of time required outside of class for service hours-- a lot of the time conflicted with student practices or other academic/club events; would love if they added more virtual service options or ways to receive hours that are not in person to account for this
This course was very well planned and implemented as it facilitated a lot of learning opportunities and the ability to develop other very helpful skills as well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! ASL is a fun and engaging class, although L3 is definitely a step up (in terms of difficulty and workload) than L1/L2.
Yes! It was so amazing learning more about ASL and Deaf culture.

I would definitely recommend this to any student that can fit it into their schedule. The staff is unbelievably wonderful especially Professor Colin. I am yet to find a more understanding and kind teaching staff as the ASL department. They are great teachers and do their best to provide each individual with what they need to succeed.
I would. ASL is an incredibly useful language to know and the ASL department is excellent.
